https://doi.org/10.1017/CBO9780511894527.004 Published online by Cambridge University Press SECURITY COUNCIL AUTHORISATION AND COLLECTIVE MEASURES Other than self-defence under Article 51, the only other exception to the prohibition on the use of force under the UN Charter is the authorisation of collective security measures under Chapter VII. The Security Council has ‘primary responsibility for the maintenance of international peace and security’ and may recommend or authorise member states to engage in measures, which may include the use of force, in order to pursue this aim. Article 39 provides: The Security Council shall determine the existence of any threat to the peace, breach of the peace, or act of aggression and shall make recommendations, or decide what measures shall be taken in accordance with Articles 41 and 42, to maintain or restore international peace and security.
This raises two separate issues for the use of computer network attacks. First, when will the Security Council consider computer network attacks to be a ‘threat to the peace, breach of the peace, or act of aggression’; and second, under what circumstances might measures authorised by the Security Council under Chapter VII include computer network attacks?
As noted, prior to the Security Council recommending action, it must determine that a ‘threat to the peace, breach of the peace, or act of aggression’ exists under Article 39. In practice, the Council has almost exclusively exercised its powers by finding a ‘threat to international peace and security’, even in situations where a breach of the peace or act of aggression is obvious;¹⁵² thus the analysis will concentrate on this broader standard. Whether or not there are any limits on the Security Council’s ability to determine a threat to the peace is the subject of debate amongst legal scholars;¹⁵³ however, it is generally accepted that the Council possesses considerable discretion in this respect. He argues that a threat to the peace exists when, in a particular situation, a danger of the use of force on a considerable scale arises.[160] Although the Security Council has not considered any computer network attacks to date,[161] based on this assessment it would certainly appear that a computer network attack would constitute a threat to the peace where it is of sufficient gravity that a state is likely to respond to it with force, regardless of whether it is categorised as an armed attack, or where the type of attack indicates further violence to follow, whether electronically or by kinetic means.
Once the Security Council has determined a threat to the peace, the Council may make recommendations, or require states to take action under Articles 40, 41 and 42 of the Charter, for the restoration or maintenance of international peace and security. Where non-forceful measures have been unsuccessful, or if the Security Council determines that such measures would be inadequate, the Council may authorise action under Article 42 by such air, sea or land forces as may be necessary to maintain or restore international peace and security; examples include demonstrations, blockade and other operations by air, sea or land forces of Members of the United Nations.¹⁶⁷ It appears unlikely that the Security Council would consider it necessary to authorise force against a computer network attack; however, where an attack or ongoing series of attacks cannot be prevented or stopped by electronic means, it is within their purview to do so. As noted earlier, force is not necessarily the preferred means of countering a cyber attack because of the distributed nature of many methods of attack.
A more interesting scenario is the possibility of the Security Council authorising computer network attacks of sufficient gravity to amount to a use of force in response to a threat to the peace. For example, in the past few years the Security Council has passed a series of resolutions expressing its concern over the proliferation risks presented by the Iranian nuclear programme.¹⁶⁸ Although the Council has not explicitly stated that it considers that the programme represents a threat to international peace and security, this is far from unusual; it is clear from the practice of the Council that no formal pronouncement with an express reference to Article 39 is necessary; the use of the language is apparently sufficient.¹⁶⁹ The Council does, however, explicitly state that it is acting under Article 41 of Chapter VII of the Charter, and each resolution calls for member states to implement a series of specific non-forceful measures against Iran. ## 7. Conclusion
As with the discussion in the previous chapter relating to the use of force, the classification of computer network attacks as armed attacks sits on top of a deep doctrinal divide between those who would argue for a wide interpretation of the right to self-defence and those who would restrict it. The present author believes that in regard to computer network attacks, a restrictive view of the armed attack threshold and the subsequent right to self-defence is preferable. Classification of computer network attacks which would amount to armed attacks should therefore be restricted to those attacks which cause physical damage to property or persons of a sufficient scale and effect. Given the particular difficulties and length of time involved in accurately attributing attacks and the fact that states acting in self-defence are not restricted to responding in kind, the danger of computer network attacks escalating into traditional conflict is apparent. That is not to say that states cannot respond to computer network attacks that do not rise to the level of an armed attack; a state may still respond with proportionate countermeasures or appeal to the Security Council for a finding that the attacks amount to a threat to the peace.
